After a brief lesson in American history, British kids will probably have a fine time. And there's just enough double-edged comedy to keep grown-ups from squawking too.
De Niro and Stallone still have just enough in their lockers to throw and take a half decent fake punch.
It's so entertaining even Liverpool fans will gobble it up.
Nobody can write this stuff like Stallone and nobody can play it like Statham.
Old fashioned it may be, but it's Disney's best films in years.
Jackson barely puts a hairy foot wrong for an action-packed two hours and 40 minutes.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Great acting and smart dialogue are a killer combination. This touching, wise and spiky romance really crawls under your skin.
Get ready for some vintage Burgundy.
One of the very best films of the year.
The catchy tunes, goofy slap-stick and bright and breezy animation all seem perfectly honed to little minds.
Technically, this is a hugely impressive film but it still left me feeling a little underwhelmed.
Despite its raunchy setting, this is easy-going, forgettable stuff that washes over you like an episode of Last Of The Summer Wine.
It's touching and, at times, very funny.
Colin Firth puts in the performance of his career in this powerful and accomplished drama based on the memoirs of Eric Lomax.
Of course, it's schmaltzy and very contrived. But if you're in the right mood, you might also find it rather touching.
There's little doubt that this painfully authentic adaptation of former slave Solomon Northup's memoir is an important film. But it is not an easy one to sit through.
An engaging and worthwhile new take on De Palma's blood-soaked classic.
An engaging, rambling affair that is pleasant to watch and easy to forget. But it does the job of proving that there's a lot more to Michael Cera than previously met the eye.
We're left guessing over what possessed this free spirit to risk her life on such a seemingly pointless task. After seeing this achingly beautiful film, you'll be very glad she did.
The ending fails to pack an emotional punch. But Pfister and Paglen have come up with something unusual - a sci-fi blockbuster that's genuinely surprising.
An old-fashioned kiddie flick with a straightforward story, simple characters, a heartfelt message and impressive 3D flying scenes. Smaller children should love it.
There's probably just enough here to take the lads over the finishing line. But they're panting rather heavily.
Sylvester Stallone isn't ready to throw in the towel on his geriatric action franchise just yet.
It seems Besson has been saving up all his Frenchness for this - the most pretentious B-movie of all time.
Radcliffe's fan club might get something out of this. But it had me pining for the grittier work of Lopez, Aniston and Diaz.
The wonder of the special effects and the immersive power of fake amateur footage are a winning combination. Find the biggest screen with the biggest speakers and prepare to be blown away.
Not much has changed in Sin City, but if you enjoyed your last visit more of the same should be more than enough.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Cynical and sentimental it may be but it still packs a punch.
This amnesia thriller is one of the most memorable films of the year.
Diaz and Segel manage to coax a few laughs out of a thin premise but there's nothing they can do with director Jake Kasdan's lame and surprisingly tame slapstick.
Pattinson impresses with a pared-down performance in an extremely pared down film. This is one of those Australian post apocalyptic road movies that keeps almost everything under its bonnet.
Director Matthew Warchus coaxes great performances from a fine ensemble cast, while first-time screenwriter Stephen Beresford deftly balances tears with some very big laughs.
Laika's beautifully animated third feature is another that isn't afraid to stand out from the crowd.
Nobody can call this Taken In A Graveyard. Matt Scudder is Neeson's most intriguing role in years.
Maybe this all seemed very sharp on stage. On the big screen it's like being hit repeatedly over the head with a croquet mallet.
This could have worked with a sharper script and better casting. But Firth finds it hard to cope with Allen's stilted dialogue.

The comedy and the tragedy are deftly balanced but what impresses the most is the way everything unfolds from the children's perspective. As we drop down a couple of feet, it's the adult world that needs to grow up.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The parts for this vigilante flick may have come off the shelf but Fuqua has fashioned them into one of the slickest action flicks of the year.
Deliciously dark and utterly gripping, this tightly-coiled teaser delivers disturbing answers to some very awkward questions.
Once again, we get an against-the-odds, mid-air battle among exploding skyscrapers and fleeing extras. But it's beautifully realised in eye-popping 3D.
The actors aren't given much room to explore their characters. But what we do get is lots of authentic-looking and thrillingly staged battle scenes.
A grim, gruesome, gripping thriller that gets funnier and nastier in equal measures.

Sadly, Aja isn't content with comedy. He also wants to make a whodunnit, a love story and a touching coming-of-age drama. That is too much for one movie to bear and way too much to ask of the young Radcliffe.
It didn't do it for me. I spent nearly as much time looking at my watch as I did gazing at Spall and Pope's great work.
A scary, stylish, beautifully acted and, for the most part, refreshingly original haunted house movie.
It's beautifully shot, smartly written and packed with suspense. But Top Boy director Yann Demange and Black Watch writer Gregory Burke do slightly over-egg the plot.
Susanne Bier has delivered a sumptuous costume drama fronted by two talented leads who gamely throw themselves head first into a delightfully preposterous plot.
I'm not entirely sure who to blame for the muddled plot but I'm pointing a finger at the Koreans.
A pacy, thoughtful, imaginative and hugely entertaining B-movie.
The comparisons with E.T. don't serve it particularly well -- this doesn't carry a fraction of that film's emotional weight.
It brings something back to the big screen that's been in short supply since the invention of the DVD extra - a sense of wonder.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Anderson is one of the few film-makers who can justify the 3D surcharge for an eyepopping CGI spectacular like this. Yet when Vesuvius blows, it doesn't carry the weight of ancient tragedy. Such is the build-up, it almost comes as a blessed relief.
Walker's character, a revenge-seeking cop, is paper-thin, the plot is riddled with holes and the clunky dialogue feels like it's been passed through Google Translate.

The plot, which is supposedly based on a true story but plays out like an episode of Hustle, is deliciously twisty. But it's the clever dialogue and a dastardly turn from Alfie Allen that really makes it tick.
It's puerile, smutty and packed with huge laughs. But it's the well-drawn and very believable characters who make this so much more entertaining than your usual frat house comedy.
In the end, it's the lure of his star that does for Ayers' movie. After a couple of very unlikely plot twists, the film quickly turns into a standard, Arnie action vehicle.
It's the songs that are the film's biggest surprise. Abrahamson and his musical cast have made Frank's unpronounceable group Soronprfbs sound like a real band.
The football is dreadful but the colourful players - like transgender defender Jaiyah Saelua - make this hilarious documentary a big-hearted delight.
A spectacular and surprisingly respectful take on the Japanese icon. Godzilla tramples other monster movies underfoot.
It's beautifully shot and quietly absorbing. But the low-level tension never really threatens to bubble over.
It's all such rollicking fun it's hard to care about the occasional baffling moment.
Parents will have definitely have sat through a lot worse. But I'm not sure what the average four-year-old will get out of it.
Witty, clever, thrilling - it could easily turn out to be the blockbuster of the year.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Part action film, part fairy tale, part feminist parable, it will interesting to see if this strange mash-up will find an audience. It's perhaps a bit dark for the Frozen crowd but I suspect older girls will be utterly enchanted.
As big-screen romances go, this is a far cry from An Affair To Remember. It's an affair you'll probably forget on the bus trip home.
This isn't the worst biopic of a princess who died in a car crash starring a miscast Aussie that has ever been made.
Director Mike Flanagan has decided that bending our minds is far more effective than drenching us in buckets of gore or jolting us out of our seats with loud noises.
As teen romances go, this is powerful stuff. For a cancer weepie, it's a very rare thing indeed - an honest film that earns every tear.
This muddled, over-long and increasingly dull comedy action flick really is no way to relaunch a movie career
Like the best karaoke turns, it's cheesy, rough around the edges and doesn't take itself at all seriously. I think that's what makes it so endearing.

This isn't a particularly memorable film. It borrows too much from other movies to stand out in it's own right. But it's a surprising one. What makes this odd 80s mash-up so intriguing is the way it's almost impossible to second guess.

First-time director Steven Reeves crafts the suspense beautifully. The film's scale - he uses a handful of actors and even fewer locations - means it will probably feel more at home on the small screen. But it is packed with some very big surprises.
This generous, big-hearted, funny and touching little film goes down a treat.
This isn't just a more soulful movie, it's a much more spectacular one too. At times, it makes it's glossy rivals look like they belong in the Dark Ages
Once you've worked out that the plot is even more ridiculous than you feared there's not much to hold your interest.
Stupid it may be but it's a lot better than the last two episodes. The plot is easier to follow, the special effects are even more spectacular and, for once, the movie has an acceptable leading man.
This tubby loser routine is already wearing a bit thin.
Touching, funny, big-hearted and recklessly ambitious.
With its sketchy plot, clunky comedy and painful soundtrack this will be a test of patience for parents.
This isn't quite as funny as the original. It does, however, come pretty close. By poking fun at the whole idea of a comedy sequel, Lord and Miller have hit on a new vein of comedy gold.
Whenever the slapstick and the shouting begins to grate, the script reels you back in with a sharply written line.
In a year when big-budget sci-fi flicks have played it safe or pandered to Asia, this hones in on old-school action fans.
The edginess is just window dressing. The message is as schmaltzy as anything you'd find in a kooky rom-com.
Films that can charm kids and adults in equal measure are rare. This is one of them.
This edgier Parker feels a more believable alter-ego - closer to the wise-cracking, ass-kicking hero from the comics and early animated TV series.

Adults hoping for the double-layered comedy of the Shrek series will be left disappointed. Still, smaller children will probably be enthralled by the action and the animators' beautifully rendered 3D visuals.
It's not an easy watch but seeing this dignified man refusing to be cowed by his persecutors is utterly gripping.
Ralph Fiennes is on great form as violent convict Magwitch and Helena Bonham Carter was born to play deranged jilted bride Miss Havisham.
Walken is such a joy, I felt like instantly rewinding his every scene. But amazingly, he doesn't completely steal the show
Both actors are superb. And the story, while perhaps a little too slight for the big screen, delivers more than enough surprises to keep its audience hooked.
An enjoyable but largely forgettable comedy drama.
There are some funny moments and some sharp lines but it's the chemistry between the two likeable leads that makes this so undeniably sweet.

It's easy to spot the padding in this over-long, character-packed, bladder-testing, 162-minute first instalment. But there's still more than enough here to make it a worthy addition to the Oscar-laden fantasy series.
IF three series of Glee haven't dented your enthusiasm for snarky comedy interspersed with glossy a cappella "mash-ups" this one could be for you.
It's hardly cutting-edge stuff but Hoffmann, 75, is clearly in his element working with these talented British veterans.
"It would take a week mucking out a pork pie factory to acclimatise for a hamfest as nauseating as this."
This doesn't look like a genuine Coen Brothers' film to me.
It's witty, has a handsome cast and plenty of zippy action but it's not one you will still be thinking of in ten years' time.
It's smart, well made, mostly well acted and quirky enough to get a cult following. But you'll need a stronger stomach than mine to enjoy it.
Thanks to brilliant acting and clever improvised dialogue, this is one of the most naturalistic depictions of teenage life I can remember seeing on the big screen.
Taking a leaf out of Scream director Wes Craven's book, Joss Whedon both uses and skewers horror film clichés for this enjoyable tongue-in-cheek slasher.
Thrilling, stylish, funny, brutal, superbly-acted, sharply written and wonderfully offensive.
Fans of great writing, superb acting, beautiful photography and the rousing scores of John Williams are going to lap this one up.
Bigelow and Boal are not in the business of providing easy answers. But they are trying to turn out a gripping, tense, political thriller. And this one is a masterpiece.
You might find the political tub-thumping behind this cockle-warming drama a tad disconcerting.

In Buried, Ryan Reynolds spends the whole film underground in a coffin - child's play compared to what Anna Walton is put through here. She spends an entire night locked in a car with Danny Dyer - while he acts at her.
Denzel Washington's face says more in the first ten seconds of this film than Zemeckis managed with over five hours of dead-eyed computer imagery.
Colin Farrell is a comedy genius.
It may start off edgy but it ends with a double helping of schmaltz.
A very funny and surprisingly sweet mash-up of a zombie action film and Romeo & Juliet. It's a bit like a Twilight movie but with better effects and a smarter script. And weirdly, a lot less moping.
Witty, inventive, beautifully animated and, most importantly, heartfelt.
By the time Amanda Sieyfried and Eddie Redmayne were warbling a love song at each other within seconds of meeting, I was ready to give in to my bladder.

If you are going to baffle an audience for nearly three hours, you'd better make sure you have a damn good pay-off. But like the last two Matrix films, this peters out into embarrassing hippy drivel about reincarnation and cosmic interconnectedness.
Silver Linings Playbook is a rare thing indeed - a romantic comedy that completely delivers on both sides of the equation.
Tom, we're really not worthy.
A beautifully shot, powerful, old-fashioned family flick told by smart and responsible adults.
This pulse-racing thriller, set in the aftermath of Iran's Islamic Revolution, grabs you by the throat.
The jokes are built almost entirely around references to old black and white horror movies.
On the evidence of this cheesy sequel, Neeson is in danger of becoming the new Steven Seagal.
The most original British gangster flick in years.
For a frantic, action-packed 80-odd minutes, it seldom puts a foot, paw or cloven hoof wrong.
The worlds of Wall Street and Goodfellas collide beautifully in this violent, witty and hugely entertaining film about a crumbling mafia empire.
Hawke is utterly convincing as the driven but dodgy writer and Derrickson has great fun infecting the quivering audience with his hero's creeping paranoia.
Director Genndy Tartakovsky has fashioned something even the most sensitive little flowers in your family can enjoy.
Like its hero, this smart, funny and beautifully animated film achieves great things by daring to be different.
Displaying a self-confidence that would put Muhammad Ali to shame, Kazan has cast herself as her real-life boyfriend's fantasy woman.
A very strange and rather disgusting indie thriller.
By the last half hour the film has descended into a procession of totally un-scary and mostly boring random images.
As charity is a big part of Christmas, I'll say the improvised comedy is a bit patchy. But as with the original, the movie comes into its own during the big finale.
There's nothing like a terminal illness for firing up a sappy romantic drama.
Winstone shows he's got what it takes to slide into John Thaw's acrylic flares.
It's the performances that really carry this film. Cole's intense portrayal marks him as one to watch and rapper English Frank also impresses as the prison's posturing, cod Jamaican kingpin Jake.
Using interviews, archive footage and a creepy original soundtrack, director Rodney Ascher ponders what makes Kubrick's film such a draw among geeks and conspiracy theorists.
The only misfire involves the trio's search for a mystery song. The fact that this shower has heard of Nick Drake but not David Bowie is really beyond belief.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The smartest, most stylish and most outright entertaining science-fiction film of the year.
Weirdly - and probably for entirely the wrong reasons - I couldn't take my eyes off it.
For a flabby 101-minute movie, the gag hit rate is alarmingly low.
MacFarlane is reduced to making increasingly laboured references to the 1980s.
The flat, non-rhyming dialogue and mainly dull new characters don't feel particularly Seussian. But thankfully, the animation does.
It's the musical numbers and the mighty lungs of Australian Idol winner Jessica Mauboy that make this one of the feel-good movies of the year.
Strange and deeply creepy.
Only the faint-hearted or KFC kitchen staff should give it a miss.
Majestically directed, masterfully acted and brilliantly written, it's not just the best British film of the year but the best film of the year - full stop.
Grim, stylish, relentlessly violent - this is the balls-to-the-wall Dredd movie fans have been waiting for.
Ballsy, bonkers and certifiably brilliant.
Yes, it's utter trash. But if, like me, you've spent weeks sitting through overlong, award-baiting dramas, this gleefully cheesy treat should hit the spot.
Gripping, stylish and delightfully pulpy.
It's the background of the Troubles that gives this rousing biopic its edge.
Like most of Boyle's work, this is a stylish and clever film. But it's also one of the few that I don't feel like going back to.
A witty and rather surprising take on the superhero movie.

Coogan puts in a restrained turn as the puddle-deep soft porn billionaire who only occasionally brings to mind a certain Norfolk DJ. But he's such a cold fish it's hard to care about his impending fall.
It's not exactly groundbreaking but it still takes a lot of brains to craft something as brazenly stupid as this.
It's beautifully photographed, whimsically narrated by Tim Allen and keeps completely schtum about the rough sex and the cannibalism.
There are a couple of decent action scenes but this is just too ridiculous to be taken as seriously as it expects to be. With a slight re-edit, it could be re-released as Naked Gun 4.
Parents may have to take a back seat here but their young charges will be enthralled by this beautifully animated 3D adventure.
Got To Dance winner Akai Osei has all the moves and Horrid Henry star Theo Stevenson has charm by the bucket load.
This strange film never really finds the right tone, feeling a little too serious for a pulpy horror flick and a lot too pulpy for a serious drama.
From the superb opening assault on a gridlocked Philadelphia this thrilling action movie barely pauses for breath.
If you thought the Smiths had a hard time of it in their last movie, heaven knows they're miserable now.
Douglas is simply brilliant here. It's far more than an impression - he simply disappears into the role of the troubled showman.
After the dull last Die Hard, this all-American slice of hokum is the gung-ho blast action fans have been craving.
Almost criminally, the star-struck director turns his camera off during the back-stage rows and fails to coax any new revelations out of his idols.
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It all plays out a bit like a feature-length episode of Dawson's Creek - pretty teenagers wandering around romantic locations spouting over-written dialogue.
When Coppola took a laid-back approach in her highly acclaimed Somewhere, I was bored to tears. But this time it's not only completely fitting but weirdly compelling.
When the smoke finally clears you won't hear a single gasp. The groans could be deafening though.
It's precisely the type of film the critics hate. Ignore them, yahoo'd be a fool to miss it.
The Book Of Revelation comes to pass in rapturous fashion while some of its brightest young stars are partying in James Franco's L.A. mansion.
Fiendishly entertaining.
A stonking summer blockbuster that delivers on an epic scale.
What is extraordinary about Gulli is how ordinary he is.
Iron Man 3 may have had better jokes and Man Of Steel slicker effects but this has more soul than the pair of them. Which is why, for me, it's the most gripping comic book movie of the year.
Gorgeously shot, brilliantly acted and recklessly ambitious.
The funniest film of the year by a Norfolk mile.
There are eye-catching special effects and some tantalising early scenes. But Blomkamp seems to have got lost in his big pile of Hollywood dollars
In this age of never-ending franchises and pointless reboots it's quite refreshing to see a funny, action-packed film that's so utterly disposable.

For the last half-hour, the director uses every trick in the book (rain machines, epic music, close-ups of sobbing girls) in a bid to jerk our tears. It was too much, too late. I was already looking at my watch.

The wizard may not be wonderful enough to warrant a film of his own but the sidekicks and special effects make Disney's much-anticipated prequel a solidly entertaining, if not quite magical, family adventure.
Dreary, ridiculous and utterly unfathomable.
A stunning and memorable debut.
The film could have done with fewer characters and a tighter plot but it's still an accomplished debut for director Rufus Norris.
It does sag in the middle but its witty enough to make realise how charmless the latest Die Hard film is.
In the end, the cards fall roughly where you'd expect them to in a clichéd thriller.
There are just enough twists to the old formula to keep you guessing to the end.
It's the way Gere and director Nicholas Jarecki create sympathy for the devil that makes this so gripping.
Refreshingly, this is a London-based crime flick that completely breaks with the usual chirpy Cockney formula. But have we really got to the stage where we have to tool-up Mr Tumnus?
Director Don Scardino plays it too safe to make this a cult classic but he does provide a few very funny set pieces.
See this and you'll never be able to look Frodo Baggins in the eye again.
Daniels probably makes the mistake of putting character and atmosphere ahead of plot. But with a cast like this you can hardly blame him.

The film, which plays a little like a real-life Rain Man, may be a bit rough around the edges but that only adds to its charm. Kate and Will show their relationship with their brother in all its messiness.
Relentlessly witless.
The CGI wolf would have been rubbish a decade ago, the clearly indoor village set looks like it once featured in an old episode of Star Trek and the central love story is lacking in bite.
Raucous, funny and disgracefully entertaining.
Singer is more concerned with old-fashioned storytelling than chasing a target audience's fleeting fads.
In what ends up as a nightmarish fusion of Glee and Sister Act 2, a mixed-race church choir makes a bid for glory by painfully "Christianising" scraps of once perfectly acceptable pop songs.
Diaz's plotline seems to revolve solely around an argument with Morrison over the merits of circumcision. She's pro-cut. He's fanatically anti-cut. Clearly, as is the film's editor.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Badly-directed trash which looks like it might have been shot and edited on a mobile phone.
Unbelievably lazy.
With Paul Newman no longer with us, no other actor could have fitted so snugly into the legendary outlaw's old boots.
It's the attention to detail that really shivers the timbers.
movie_title: The Pirates! An Adventure With Scientists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There's a lot more to this likeable crime flick than your usual dunderheaded Danny Dyer vehicle.
The laziest, most cack-handed, most unromantic and most excruciatingly unfunny rom-com I can remember having to sit through.
An irritating 130-minute dripathon.
It may not be laughably awful - like her and Ritchie's Swept Away - it's something far worse...boring.
It's another great performance from the star who appears now to have mastered the fed-up stare.
It's a brave plan to make a cancer movie that's moving, uplifting and pant-wettingly funny. But against the odds, it's definitely a case of remission accomplished.
A new Christmas classic.
Plucking the audience's heartstrings feels like the worst possible way to make a film about someone called The Iron Lady.
It's crushingly disappointing when it falls apart so completely in the second half.
It's Downey Jr's meatiest role in years...if only it wasn't served with such a thick layer of cheese.
Sparks' usual mixture of female self-sacrifice, sensitive tough guys, unlikely twists and frequent dashes to the hospital. It's a familiar cocktail but it packs a real punch.
The final stretch may be just a little too hard to swallow. But fans of smart, spectacular sci-fi will still gulp down this astonishing trip through the cosmos.
If you are suffering from The Brexit Blues, then watching a tiny comic repeatedly clocking a hulking muscle man around the chops could be just what the doctor ordered.
Spacey v Shannon is a fascinating showdown between two Hollywood heavyweights.
McCarthy is a brilliant physical comedian. But boy, does she need a decent director.
[A] dull biopic of the legend of the Grand Ole Opry.
Bond and Bourne fans will notice the drop in budget, but this rollicking spy flick will fill a gap until Matt Damon returns to the spy game in July.
Hard-hitting, beautifully shot and wonderfully acted.
The story unfolds pretty much as expected.
As Egerton's gurning, one-note performance is beginning to lose its charm, Jackman's A-list grit arrives just in time.

The thrilling action sequences in medieval Spain provide a glimpse of how a less convoluted version could have played out. But whenever we're about to get lost in the action, Kurzel yanks us back into the present day for more hogwash.
Shyamalan is clearly having fun here and we're laughing with him. As I said, it's a big improvement on After Earth.
Joyous, romantic and achingly stylish.
It's clever, well-written and well acted. But not quite what I expected from a Trainspotting sequel.

It's not as brainy as The Big Short, as witty as American Hustle or as entertaining as The Wolf of Wall Street. But this slightly muddled tale does unearth something golden -- another glittering turn from Matthew McConaughey
This "block" buster definitely won't disappoint.

As wonderfully crafted as they are (and for me the choreography knocks La La Land into a cocked hat), there's always a danger the violence could become a bit numbing. Thankfully, the film-makers know precisely when to puncture the killing with comedy.
This is very unusual blockbuster - a Vietnam war flick, a comedy and an old-fashioned creature feature in one monstrously entertaining package. It's bananas but brilliant.
Cleary, there's still plenty of Disney magic in this fairytale.
At least this bizarre Power Rangers movie tries to do something to stand out from the crowd.
If you're in the "they don't make them like they used to" camp, you'll have a great time being proved wrong.
Lone Scherfig may be Danish, but she's knows precisely how to make a Brit flick tick.
It may be missing a standout shock but Covenant keeps it's promise to horror fans.
She's fearless, whip-smart and she's just saved the Universe. After three false starts, director Patty Jenkins has delivered the first great film in the DCEU.
I feel duty bound to kick sand in the face of director Seth Gordon. But to be honest, I just don't have it in me. I found myself laughing seven or eight times during his Baywatch spoof.

The film offers Walking Dead style fights and clunky comedy blatantly ripped off from An American Werewolf In London. If Universal hope to take on Wonder Woman and Iron Man at the box office, they'll have to go back to the drawing board.
After two hours of this drivel, I was praying for the end credits.
Sadly, the flabby script doesn't offer this talented actor nearly enough to sink his teeth into. I spent the first half rolling my eyes and the second half fighting to keep them open.
Webb has uncovered a real gifted child in McKenna Grace, who is touching, charming and refreshingly unaffected as the reluctant little genius.
This is the best Ice Age movie since the first one.
Hopefully, enough Marvel kids can be persuaded to check this old-fashioned superhero. Tarzan is swinging again.

Director Mat Whitecross cleverly focuses on the band's best period -- beginning on the council estates of Burnage in 1991 and ending five years later in front of a quarter of a million fans at Knebworth.
Great performances from both actors sell the romance and the struggle. This is an inspiring true story that really deserves to be retold.
DreamWorks have found a very underhand way to flog those hairy collectable dolls - they've made them the stars of their most enjoyable film since Shrek.
A road movie that refuses to go anywhere. It's big on atmosphere and art house clichés but fatally thin on plot.

For the most part, this is a series of frenetic chases through tourist hot spots. They come in such quick succession, you might not examine the big twist until you're on your way home. As it makes roughly zero sense, this is a good thing.
Not quite the chariot crash I was secretly hoping for. The dialogue is dull rather than cheesy, the acting is disappointingly proficient and the 3D CGI effects are actually rather good.
A rollicking B-flick enlivened by a stellar performance from its leading man.

Rowling's latest trick is to cross Doctor Who with Doctor Dolittle. Newt and his menagerie provide just enough surprises for an action-packed couple of hours. But the magic man isn't quite as spellbinding as the wizard boy.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This instalment isn't about looking backwards. In essence, it's a war movie and director Gareth Edwards keeps the momentum going with a string of stunning set pieces.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There may be no atmosphere in space but the chemistry sparks.
The film's messages -- the importance of tolerance and following your dreams -- are pretty standard for a kiddie flick. But there's a political edge that is very unusual for a Disney movie.
This summer's superhero films may have fallen a bit flat but this one is magic.
[A] gripping detective story and brilliant newpaper drama.
The dialogue is flat, the plot lacks coherence and the characters are underwritten.
In it's own way, this beautifully shot, brilliant acted and smartly written movie is as exciting as Independence Day or War of the Worlds.
It's charming, gently amusing and Rock Dog doesn't strum too loudly on his guitar.
Touching and achingly funny.
It's more entertaining than Batman v Superman, the first film in the new DC Comics franchise, but compared with Guardians Of The Galaxy, Marvel's offbeat ensemble, it's anything but super.
It's touching, magical, heartfelt and, in the Disney tradition, is prepared to explore its forest setting's darker byways.
It may be off its trolley but it also feels fresh out of the packet.
Peter Berg's restaging of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion in the Gulf of Mexico is spectacular and bracingly realistic.
The really offensive thing about it is how lazy it is.
Brilliant Streep wails hilariously and Grant bumbles expertly as Frears turns a true story into an old-fashioned farce. But it's the film's emotional beats that really make it sing.
Thankfully, this third outing for Renée Zellweger's singleton is a lot more worthwhile than the recent returns of Zoolander and the Terminator.
No one plays no-nonsense heroes like Tom Hanks and no director admires them quite so much as Clint Eastwood.
Sounds dreadful doesn't it? Believe or not it, it gets a whole lot worse.
It's an intriguing and very timely story, even if the tension and credibility aren't quite up to the standards of 2011's brilliant Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy.

Depending your politics, Snowden's revelations about the US secret electronic surveillance system make him a patriot or a traitor. Stone is so determined to show him as the former, he also makes him a bit of a bore.
Unlike most of this year's blockbusters, his "Thoroughly Entertaining Seven" hits most of its targets.
This bonkers but brilliant premise means this is one of the more preposterous action movies of the year. It's also one of the most entertaining.
Stanton takes aim at the heart instead of the head. This is another touching fable about friendship, self-reliance and courage.
Pensioners may be able to get cheap daytime tickets but they don't deserve cut price drama.
The drama is short on tension but Gleeson's performance is gripping.
This beautifully shot film will be catnip to fans of felines.
Not quite a classic, but this smart and visually stunning sequel will still be poured over by fans for years to come. If this was a poisoned chalice, Villeneuve has grabbed it with both hands.
Bruckner summons up some nightmarish images before letting loose with a gleefully over-the-top finale.
Witty dialogue, likeable performances, creepy atmosphere and an unusual set-up.
The Lego Ninjago Movie could be the funniest film of 2017.
Despite Fassbender's best efforts, we don't see inside the hero's head.
Branagh has given a familiar tale some extra bite.
The dialogue could be wittier but the scary scenes are short-lived, the pace is brisk and the message is big-hearted.
It's well-meaning but a more exciting movie might have been a better tribute.
This beautifully shot, smartly-written and wonderfully-cast drama is grim and joyful in equal measures.
It's as unlikely and as charming as a talking bear... a cute family film topping my list of the best films of the year.
After the excellent Wonder Woman, DC plays it safe with a very familiar debut mission for their superhero tag team.
Lithgow and Ferrell deliver a smattering of laughs, but they come with a very bitter aftertaste.
The characters are dull and defiantly unlikeable, the acting is wooden, the score is overbearing and its point is elusive.
This moving and eye-opening biopic reveals life was no picnic for the creators of "the bear of very little brain".
The film may borrow the name from the much-hyped match, but Little Miss Sunshine directors Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris know far more interesting conflicts were playing out off the court.
The film's best sections involve Plummer, who on this evidence would make a great Scrooge in the 20th straight adaptation of the novella. They should have bitten the bullet and made that instead.
This is a film with heart as well as humour.
The clever Better Watch Out finds a fresh way to add some unwholesome fun to the holiday season.
This warts-and-all account ensures that every tear will be earned.
This isn't the first quirky indie film to extol the virtues of quirky indie-film-making but it manages to be sweet, surprising and consistently amusing.
This may be nonsense but it's well-meaning and, most importantly, entertaining nonsense.
As Sorkin's loquacious heroine engaged in rapid-fire exchanges with her whip-smart lawyer (Idris Elba), I could almost hear the clickety clack of the writer's keyboard.
It was an expensive gamble but it has paid off handsomely. [Christopher] Plummer is the best thing in the film.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are good things in this small package but the two genres never quite fit together.
A spectacular and surprisingly thoughtful action movie.
[A] joyous claymation comedy ...
For all Anderson and Day-Lewis's accomplishments I found it almost impossible to care about this preening bully and his latest conquest.
It does to Adam Sandler's manchild movies what Bridesmaids did to gross-out comedies. It flips the gender and adds charm and decent jokes.
It's kind, but it doesn't feel quite right.
It's Blunt's convincing turn as the sozzled Rachel that keeps us gripped.
It looks like Masud is going to be one hell of a player.

As this is such an interesting true story (or a "mostly" true story as an opening caption reveals), this feels like a cop-out. At times, I was convinced I could see the ghost of a grittier early draft.
While Wright is a master stylist, I'm still not convinced he is a great storyteller.
It feels a lot less focused that the first two films but it's big-hearted and consistently amusing.
Zippy, witty and thoroughly enjoyable ...
This is a stylish film that is constantly asking us questions. Sadly, answers are infuriatingly thin on the ground.
Connery delivers a touching father/son relationship and an interesting look at the moral certainties of Victorian Britain.
Few summer blockbusters make the brain tick and the heart race at the same time -- this could turn out to be the blockbuster of the summer.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The tills in the Disney Stores should keep ringing ... thanks to a string of slick and moderately exciting racing scenes.
Rather dull.
Few summer blockbusters make the brain tick and the heart race at the same time. Is is too early too call this the blockbuster of the summer?
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a classic DreamWorks film but there's enough here to keep little ones laughing and parents from nodding off.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This astonishing film demands to be watched on the biggest screen available.
The footage is chilling and the heroism of these traumatised but determined young men is unquestionable.
It's a film of a thousand mistakes and Besson's arrogant decision to write his own script is the biggest of them all.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If I'd seen this unhinged, art-house horror on TV I would have probably turned it off after the preposterous opening half an hour. But by the end it had completely won me over.
This lean, mean, fighting machine is lost in a very flabby plot.
After a while, the things that irritated me about the film - the long takes, the boxy frame, the ironic costume - began to hit home.
Rush has never been better. It's a small film built around a very big performance.
Thankfully, the underwater scenes are beautifully shot - a sequence where cocky Philippe is surrounded by killer sharks is almost worth the price of admission alone.
This might have been enough for a great double act but Reynolds and Jackson don't have a molecule of the chemistry of Nick Nolte and Eddie Murphy.
It's not the worst Stephen King movie but it is one of the most forgettable. The writer's wild imagination has been flattened for a quick shot at a family hit.
For once that Colgate white smile doesn't cut it. Cruise's star wattage doesn't illuminate the story, it blinds us to its complexities.
It feels like an opportunity wasted.
Mara's English accent can be distracting, but we can feel a maelstrom of emotions raging inside this troubled young woman.
A bit dull.
Engaging but overstuffed ...
This is all great fun and as the heist begins the robbers are revealed to be a charismatic bunch with a very interesting dynamic.
Muschietti serves up yet another tale of a group of misfit BMX kids riding around a small town America trying to solve a mystery.
The film offers lots more than twists and red herrings. The dialogue is beautifully underwritten, the soundtrack is moody, cinematography stunning and the casting is faultless.
The dialogue is naff and the plot is predictable but director David F Sandberg delivers the jump scares with ruthless efficiency.
It's hardly surprising Brent's first big-screen outing is, by far, the funniest movie of the year. But I didn't expect it to be one of the most heart-breaking too.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Incoherent, pretentious and painfully self-indulgent.
Whenever you fear the whole enterprise is about to come crashing down, the brilliant Lumley hoiks it back on its feet.
Smart, funny, big-hearted, endlessly inventive and quintessentially British, this timeless, stop-motion adventure is a shear delight from start to finish.
Everything about this movie is overcooked. The sets are overdesigned, the action is over scored and the mythology overworked.
It's beautifully shot, wonderfully acted and built around a moment of suspense Hitchcock would have been proud of.
The premise is preposterous and the plot has more holes than St Andrews.
There are flashes of genius in this recycled robot movie but if feels like Blompkamp is running worryingly short of ideas.
The politics of sleeping with the enemy make for powerful viewing in this classy big-screen version of Irène Némirovsky's best-selling World War II romance.
Teenage kicks are in short supply in the preposterous second instalment of Veronica Roth's derivative Young Adult series.
Explosive, spectacular and surprisingly touching, Episode 7 is a fitting tribute to Paul Walker.
The pace is breezy and the action scenes are expertly staged. But while Bourne was shaking off his memory loss, I was hit with a severe case of déjà vu.
Reeves serves up a emphatic reminder of his action hero credentials with a charismatic and acrobatic performance.
The romance feels a bit tacked on but Crowe clearly knows how to direct a battle scene.
Tom Hardy is excellent in the lead role and director Daniel Espinosa crafts some brilliant individual scenes but the story gets a little bogged down with subplots.
The film is nicely shot, Rickman can still arch an eyebrow and the costumes and furniture are all very nice to look at. But thrill-seekers may want to look elsewhere.
Disney has swallowed up both Pixar and Marvel and this uneven animation feels like the resulting belch.
Overlong and astonishingly self-indulgent.
It ticks all the boxes for a summer blockbuster but you feel spandex fatigue is just being to creep into the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
David Nicholls deserves huge credit for condensing Hardy's sprawling melodrama into a rollicking screenplay that comes in at under two hours and still hits all the major plot points.
Smart, stylish, tense and reassuringly preposterous, it's a fitting addition to the series and a rollicking spy movie in its own right.
The banter between Allen and Dawson keeps things ticking over, it's nicely shot and there are some amusing lines. But the rambling structure requires sharper visual gags and much tougher targets.
It's a slight film, but it's amusing, pacy, action-packed and doesn't take itself remotely seriously.
Great performances, eye-popping cinematography and stunning stunts make this a thunderous comeback for the Aussie icon.
Banks deliver a steady trickle of bawdy laughs but the pacing - like Wilson - sags noticeably in the middle.
Disney's recklessly ambitious sci-fi adventure joins The Lone Ranger in the file marked "noble failure".
Smart, witty and surprisingly well cast.
Fans of samurai movies, historically inaccurate hairdos and a video camera's slow-mo button should lap up this daft swords and sandals slasher.
Consistently amusing and, during the final act, surprisingly touching. It's also a little too predictable to be a classic.
A by-the-numbers disaster flick featuring passable special effects, thinly-drawn characters, clunky dialogue and predictable plotting.
Once again, director Paul Feig has managed to the best out of Melissa McCarthy.
A solid, if very familiar, revenge Western with a decent lead, a couple of well-staged shootouts and some dazzling desert landscapes.
The mix of broad comedy and heartfelt drama never comes off. James Erksine's film displays neither enough grit nor enough wit.
One of the most ridiculously entertaining spy flicks since Roger Moore hung up his safari suit.

I did feel slightly short-changed by the level of violence. But Chandor seems interested in lower octane thrills. At its core, this atmospheric film is a study of two steely characters who are trying to keep their hands clean in a very dirty business.
Brosnan shows enough in the action scenes to make this an effective audition piece for the next Expendables movie but there's nothing here you haven't seen in countless Eurotrash thrillers.

This increasingly surreal panto has enough fart jokes to divert very young children for at least half of its hugely ambitious 109-minute running time. But to their loving parents this could be an all-singing, all-dancing nightmare.
Stylish, gripping and surprisingly thoughtful.
Funny, touching and surprisingly topical, this is an utter delight from start to finish.

This isn't about heroic firefights or gung-ho speeches. Instead, it plays out like an astonishingly realistic horror movie as these genuine heroes edge their way through an old Russian minefield to save their comrades
The plot may be predictable but Scott's film is a revelation. This is a Biblical epic we can all believe in.
It's well shot, tense and solidly entertaining. But watertight it definitely isn't.
Crossing the whimsy of The Santa Clause with the grit of Scum may sound like an odd idea but Smith manages to milk his set-up for some big laughs.

Parents might find their patience wearing thin towards the end but smaller kids should gobble it down. It hits them with such a barrage of slapstick and madcap action they'll never notice they're being told the same joke over and over again.
A betrayal at this stage would have been too much to bear. So diehards might feel like breaking into a hearty Dwarvish ballad at the end of this deeply satisfying finale.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of relying on dizzying gimmicks, Dreamworks' new animated feature simply revels in the sheer heart-pumping pleasure of watching action unfold through those Buddy Holly-style glasses.
It's breezy, big-hearted, fitfully amusing and mildly educational. If this is your ten-year-old's movie franchise of choice, you're probably on to a good thing.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Big Eyes isn't just the most traditional film Burton has ever made, it's also one of his most entertaining.
Depp massively overplays it in this embarrassing and shockingly unfunny self-produced farce.
There are some thrilling moments but the film feels less than a sum of its parts. And that's largely down to Jolie's one-note hero.
It's missing a stand-out shock but it's well-paced, stylish and, at times, deeply unsettling.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Brilliantly acted, sharply written and astonishingly shot, this oddball drama is quite rightly being tipped for Oscar glory.
Being on the run from American cops instead of wonky-shooting Albanians might not seem like much of a change but it's just enough to make Bryan interesting again.
It's almost impossible to overhype Redmayne's performance in this witty, touching and very classy British drama.
Watching doe-eyed Dwight leave his car keys at a murder scene, bungle a kidnapping and miss shooting his target from 2ft away is a tense and unpredictable experience.
Hardy gives almost nothing away for long stretches of this slow-burning thriller. He saves it all for a brutal and genuinely surprising finale.

Hoffman intrigues by keeping his cards clasped firmly to his chest. It is a restrained, controlled performance from one of the most talented screen actors of his generation. He's so good it's heartbreaking.
Tense, hilarious, harrowing, brilliantly performed and masterfully directed.
This troubling and ultimately tragic portrait of an all-American killer is Eastwood's best film in years.
Winsome Witherspoon impresses with a quiet, physical performance. But the real, extreme Cheryl seems to have got lost in the wilderness.
It's a classy, beautifully shot drama with two very photogenic leads. Yet for me it just felt too tasteful.
Garland cleverly keeps us on our toes by constantly toying with our allegiances.
The script is painfully overwritten whenever we want action and woefully underwritten when we need explanation.
You can "betcha bottom dollaaar" that this the most pointless remake of the year.
It's nicely shot, superbly acted and extremely frustrating.
I think the selfie generation has just got it's own The Breakfast Club.
The tone jumps awkwardly between soppy romance, serious drama and Carry On-style comedy.
Brainy, brilliant and intensely frustrating -- the latest Steve Jobs movie is a lot like the man himself.

What sets this apart from lesser romances is the minor characters. Nick Hornby's script (working off Colm Tóibín's best-selling novel) gives the supporting cast plenty to do. Every face fits the part perfectly.
[A] lovely little film.
Director JJ Abrams has delivered the Episode 4 fans were looking for in 1999.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The broad comedy is sporadically funny, although watching the humiliations being heaped on nice-guy Brad does get a bit exhausting.
Anarchic, outrageous and filthily funny, this tongue-in-cheek X-Men movie tears up the superhero rulebook from within.
The plot is thin and the gags are patchy but the expert timing of some of Britain's finest comedy actors has got our Home Guard heroes marching again.
If there's a worse film scheduled for release this year, I really don't want to see it.
A pacy, quirky and thoroughly entertaining family adventure.
Stallone delivers a touching and wonderfully understated performance.
A misguided retread of some of the least amusing elements of the original.
This old-fashioned yarn takes on some water at the beginning but when the rescue begins, it steams ahead.
The dialogue is cheesy, the acting creaky and the plot preposterous. London Has Fallen is everything I hoped it would be.
Welsh hats should be doffed at Rhys Ifans for producing, voicing and starring in this brave second attempt to bring Dylan Thomas's radio "play for voices" to the big screen.
Dour, disappointing and shockingly incoherent.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: After keeping his cards close to his chest for the brilliant opening half, Nichols fumbles badly on the home stretch.
This handsome follow-up seems to have been meticulously designed to please nobody.
The four-legged stars are more Discovery Channel than Disney Channel but it's the old school art of voice casting that makes this astonishing spectacle really sing.
A near-perfect blend of humour, drama and action.
Touching, thought provoking, deadly serious and oddly humorous. It's also one of the most blazingly original films I've seen in years.
Linklater has crafted another star-free, period drama that perfectly recreates the spirit of a year and the age of its characters.
Schultz's flat artwork doesn't really suit 3D and the dual stories feel a bit thin stretched over 90 minutes. But the characters are still hard to resist.
It's pacy and sporadically spectacular but after the inventive First Class and the mind-bending Days of Future Past, it does feel disappointingly formulaic.
Grim, over-stuffed and barely comprehensible, the ambitiously titled Warcraft: The Beginning could be bad enough to double up as Warcraft: The End.
If you can handle shonky special effects, cheesy dialogue and African deities who sound like they grew up in Paisley, this should be a lot of fun.
It's witty, spectacular and expertly paced by action specialist Linn who has managed to recapture the spirit of The Original Series.
The effects are impressive but Mark Rylance's performance is little short of magical.
Again, this is a film that keeps posing puzzles. Why anyone would cast Radcliffe as a villain is the first one.
If Hitchcock had ever directed an episode of The Twilight Zone, it might have looked something like this.
At no point did I give a monkey's about what happened to Nicholas Hoult's murderous, vacuous A&R man in this muddled Brit flick.
There's more than enough here to keep younger children quiet over a rainy bank holiday weekend.
Sadly, while this gothic throwback is big on design it's shockingly short on actual scares.
McKellen adds levels of shading to a character that most of his predecessors deemed unnecessary.
A tasty little treat you'll want to squirrel away for a rainy day.
The slapstick sidekicks were tasty in small portions but they don't make much of a main course.
Kaspadia uses audio interviews, scraps of unseen TV footage and grainy videos shot on phones and camcorders to show us a side of the star most of us never got to know.
One of the most compelling films about mental illness I've seen and one of the most authentic rock biopics of all time.
The comedy is muted, the action scenes are slick but forgettable and the character's USP is largely wasted.
Summer blockbusters don't get much better than this.
It's simply an old-fashioned good-versus-evil yarn. And it's all the better for it.
As a blockbuster, this comes pretty close to perfection.
Jake Gyllenhaal is becoming one of the most interesting actors in Hollywood.
Funny, stylish and knowingly preposterous, this Sixties-set adventure is just a safari suit away from a Roger Moore era Bond movie.
James and Sandler just look bored playing the same buffoons they've been playing for years.
Like Cape Fear or Fatal Attraction, the chills here come from lines being crossed and waters muddied. It's a small film but surprisingly accomplished one.
You can probably guess the twist from the trailer, but that doesn't detract from Pike's performance. In fact, with the suspense hobbled, the ball is entirely in her court. She plays it beautifully.
Films that are this sharply written, expertly directed and brilliantly acted don't come along too often.
Traditionally zombie movies are valued for their clever satire. This gross-out zom-com aims a bit lower.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This may be the longest Bond film ever made, but it's so entertaining those 148 minutes fly by faster than Bond's new gadget-laden Aston Martin DB10.

The kids are great and the change of perspective does offer some different chills to the claustrophobic first movie. But there is no big twist to look forward to. And now the ghosts have stepped out of the shadows, they just don't seem that scary.
A touching, insightful and amusing drama based on believable characters and clever ideas.
A witty, gritty survival flick that happily sacrifices good science for great entertainment.
This horribly realistic disaster movie may be set at the highest point on the planet but the drama feels surprisingly flat.
It's a slight film but an unfussy one that offers warmth, wisdom and gentle comedy.
What the film lacks in originality it makes up with thrilling action.
Like Pixar's best movies -- Up, Toy Story and Wall-E -- this blazingly original coming-of-age story achieves greatness by refusing to talk down to audiences of any size.
Unless you're watching through rose-tinted 80s glasses you should find this a worthy sequel to Chevy Chase's original.
I think there's just enough in this action-packed reboot to warrant the price of a cinema ticket.
Helgeland delivers no new revelations in this puddle-deep and fatally familiar retelling of the Krays' careers.
A proficient but largely forgettable action flick.
Director Marc Forster has cranked the action up to 11 - and in some cases, 12.
The first half's a blast, but as the comedy / action / horror / parody piles up, Hot Fuzz cools down. Needs more of a short, sharp schlock.
A riveting study in dislocation and connection, hurt and healing, with Gosling revealed as potentially the most gifted actor of his generation.
Dopey editing, ropey pacing, hokey story structure, scrappy sound, rubbish rubbery gore and acting that would shame a toddlers' nativity play.
A bitter but bracing pill. Moore constructs a fiery but unfanatical argument that boils down to a simple truth: Americans need to stop helping themselves and start helping each other.

Caine and Law rustle up a spicy chemistry which sustains a sizzle for an hour or so. But the second half panders to Pinter's self-indulgence, unravelling Branagh's high-tensile head-fuck as a hollow skirmish.

Fresh, funny and uplifting. A zingy, irresistible sorbet of light-footed comedy and everyday humanity. Only hardened churls will roll their weary eyes at Hawkins' gusto. Leigh's most open and optimistic film since Life Is Sweet.
A redemptive arc leashes the threads together, hinged on insights into familial repression that are a tad too costumedrama-stifled for their own good.
movie_title: Dean Spanley (My Talks with Dean Spanley) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As phoney and frustrating as it is funny. Baron Cohen's comedy-outsider schtick is slick but well and truly found out. The clothes may be new and more fabulous, but the emperor seriously needs to go shopping.
Game-changing - yes. Spectacular - absolutely. Occasional dodgy dialogue and dramatic imperfections - of course. But still - wait for it... - a titanic achievement.
Good looks, cool characters, great music. Gervais and Merchant's film is the most confident British debut since Shallow Grave.
It's like an episode of 24 with furrier overcoats.
It's like Psycho remade by Ed Wood.
movie_title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Beyond the daft comparisons with 2001, this is a mature film from a director who's morphing from eye-rolling agitator into eye-catching artist.
It's Eisenberg's performance that captivates -- icky and icy but strangely sympathetic.
Not quite as much fun as the from-nowhere original, but still, y'know, fackin' shocking.
It's this attention to the anxious underbelly of Victorian culture that does most to save Topsy-Turvy from descending into pictorialism.
Despite its cynical gloss on romance, High Fidelity is a sweet sentimental tale, remixed for audiences who think they're too smart for schmaltz.

Yes, you are effectively watching a special effects showcase - but no more so than Peter Jackson's Lord Of The Rings. And that was nine hours long. So go and see Avatar on the biggest screen possible - you won't regret it.
After the misstep of Quantum of Solace, first time Bond director Sam Mendes' Skyfall includes moments that match the finest points of the spy's chequered 50-year career.
A visually striking and scarily assured piece of filmmaking.
Accept the film on its own broad, crowd-pleasing terms and it is nigh-on impossible not to be swept up.
Denis Villeneuve makes this directing lark look easy - whatever the genre he seems to effortlessly step up to the plate and deliver the goods.

Yes the overarching plot is a familiar one and some of the A-list supporting players get precious little to chew on (Mads Mikkelsen is particularly short-changed as the Darth Vader-like Kaecilius), but Doc Strange does the job and then some.
McDonagh is clearly having a ball skewering every last genre cliché in the book, yet the bizarre, off-kilter world he creates is mostly just surface.
At its best it's a whole lot of fun, director Jean-François Richet (Assault on Precinct 13, Mesrine) and his game leading man serving up a tasty slice of B-movie goodness.
There's a lot of material to get through and pacing becomes a real problem, the story flashing forward one minute and then becoming ponderous and meandering the next.
The characters are so likeable and the chemistry between them so strong that you're happy to stay the course.
A stodgy snoozefest that - at least to begin with - plays out like an unintentional spoof.
Rushed pretty much sums the film up. The drastically reduced running time contributes to a ruinous mishandling of character arcs, Huston's titular hero forced to change hats far too quickly.
[A] run-of-the-mill threequel, delivering occasional bursts of preposterous, tongue-in-cheek fun but nowhere, nowhere near enough.

At its worst Jake Szymanski's film is soul-crushingly unfunny, Efron and DeVine playing bonehead brothers whose lazy, dumb-and-dumber shtick includes confusing the word "ultimatum" for "an old tomato."
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Destined to become a Friday night favourite.
For a brief moment the film recalls Steven Soderbergh's Ocean's trilogy - just without the style, substance or even a half-decent soundtrack.
Some of the quirkier touches feel a little forced but more often than not there's a winning sense of oddball charm.
A movie where the roundhouse kicks land considerably better than the quips.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As a study of the man it's named after Sully barely scratches the surface, but when you're dealing with a story this remarkable and you've got a game Tom Hanks on board surface is enough.
An animated tale that's a million miles from the irreverent brilliance of The Lego Movie, but mercifully still more than a bare-minimum cash grab.
Williams is completely believable as a man who's allowed life to pass him by, never stopping to question what it is he really wants or who he really is.
Jeff Nichols makes it four out of four with this stripped-down sci-fi thriller.
Innocuous but patience-testing, and a little out of place on the silver screen.
As always it's hard to feel too much sympathy for someone who assumes the rules (or in this case rule, singular) don't apply to them. But at least grief-stricken desperation is a fairly solid excuse.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Horror fans have their patience tested more than most, but wading through cookie-cutter, cattle-prod fare only makes you appreciate the real deal even more when it comes creeping and crawling out the woodwork.
Somehow Landesman turns a compelling true-life story into a drama that simply doesn't ring true.
Petroni serves up a hackneyed ghost story that recycles themes and ticks from the likes of The Sixth Sense, The Shining and Don't Look Now.
Feig and team make sure bustin' still feels pretty damn good.​
Broadly sticking to the boxing movie blueprint is forgivable, Teller failing to properly sell the struggle of a man whose livelihood and reason for living is almost ripped away from him isn't.
Aside from striking natural beauty there's little to recommend ...
As painfully sad as all this sounds not once does the film feel forced or overdone. Yes there's tragedy, but it always sits believably alongside the everyday.
Don't bother - you've seen it all before.
Welcome to the weird and wonderful world of competitive poultry pageantry.

The lack of any real bad blood between all-time tennis greats Björn Borg and John McEnroe makes the title a touch misleading, yet this surprisingly low-key sports drama still has a story worth telling.

Gone is the genuine heart, warmth and pathos that made the 2011 original such a wonderfully pleasant surprise, but this unruly sports comedy sequel - written and directed by Jay Baruchel - still delivers on the laughs.

Time and time again gothic murder mystery melts uncomfortably into hammy melodrama, as we jump from scenes of graphic violence and gore to a world of hoary double entendres, randy midgets and Eddie Marsan in an ill-fitting bald cap.
Oh dear.
This is about as good as it gets.
There are plenty of times when director Patrick Hughes seems to be doing his damnedest to spoil the party, but in the end star power and on-screen chemistry win out.
Grim and grubby business from start to finish, this ninety-minute product-placement nightmare is like a version of Pixar's ​Inside Out made by a sinister cabal of dead-inside marketing execs.
It's shiny, kid-friendly fun - just don't expect it to tug on the heartstrings, or live particularly long in the memory.
Reeves and co are on course to deliver something truly special. Yet it isn't quite to be.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Charming, fleet-footed and frequently hilarious, this latest take on the web-slinging do-gooder - the third since the early 2000s - is some seriously top-drawer fluff.
Attempting to alleviate the sense of crushing, overwhelming tedium with flashy visuals and stylish action sequences, when they're this few and far between, is like giving CPR to a corpse.
Too much works to get hung up on the misses - Wright's film is an absolute blast.
Thankfully there are few filmmakers on earth who can deliver violent spectacle quite like Scott.
As with the surprisingly excellent original, it's the dynamic between the cast that draws you in.
