movie_title: Thunder and the House of Magic (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Very funny underdog comedy that's genuinely heartwarming and full of charm.
Missing the punchy plotting of the Coens thriller it resembles, the early chuckles don't quite translate into a satisfying whole.
Armstrong's subsequent sojourn in Hollywood never yielded a film as engaging and passionately felt as this, her brilliant feature debut.
A clear winner that makes you laugh, cry, and generally want to party and parade like it's 1984. Respect.
Pacino's passionate look at both Salome and Wilde. It delivers in fits and starts but mostly baffles.
As entertainingly gripping as it is smartly disturbing and scathingly satirical.
Handsome, well-mounted but dull, dull, dull.
Odd-couple chemistry and a dark underbelly keep this Danish noir adaptation compelling.
movie_title: The Keeper of Lost Causes (Kvinden i buret) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Commercially it looks a disaster. Artistically, if very far from a triumph, it's interesting, almost held together by its charismatic stars.
Between the toe twinkling and ivory tickling it's still a comfortable, cosy way to pass an afternoon.
Against the odds, perhaps, but part three injects a tiring franchise with new life and some surprisingly dark jokes.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The result disappoints, despite its leads' best efforts.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Tougher than a box of nails, this is a brassy revenge thriller that refuses to pull its punches.
The word 'icon' is overused but as this charming Muhammad Ali portrait shows, occasionally it's utterly warranted.
The silliest spin-off this side of Elektra, and lots of fun with it.
Playing away from the strengths of its experience cast, this is muddled and charmless.

If this sounds like The African Queen meets Rooster Cogburn, be aware that flashes of sardonic humour and painful poignancy are to be gratefully received in a sombre, grim, frequently horrific depiction of the pioneer experience.
The cute puppy almost steals the show but Hardy is ace and quite the watchable chameleon in his surprising switch from lovable dumb ox to cannier-than-we-thought.
Pants. Groovy purple bell bottoms, but still pants.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Wright's film is warm, entertaining, and a great window into Hockney's work.
Russian Ark is an astounding technical feat that must be seen to be believed.
Williams is taking her next big step forward, graduating to full-fledged leading lady status in The Incredible Jessica James with style and charm to spare.
If you're in the mood for emotional catharsis, A Monster Calls is one of the weepiest experiences I've had at the theater this year.

Ford doesn't have anything especially new or interesting to say about the nature of vengeance or love, or the emptiness of material riches. But Nocturnal Animals has fun and looks damn good saying it. Maybe that's enough.
Headshot stops somewhere short of mind-blowing, especially if you've seen Uwais in action before, but it's another thoroughly satisfying showcase for his talents.
It's a story as old as Hollywood and jazz, and Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone feel like a pairing for the ages.
While not especially deep, the combination of a star-studded cast and an equally star-studded music catalogue make for a fun time.
The Belko Experiment isn't much more than a good time at the theater, but it isn't really trying to be and doesn't really have to be.
Vigalondo's strong vision, along with sensitive work by Hathaway and Sudeikis, ensures that Colossal never feels like anything other than completely itself.
Though the corseted bodices and full skirts suggest an Oscar bait-y period drama, Stillman quickly establishes Love & Friendship as an out-and-out comedy.
Basically every war movie ever made takes pains to point out that war is hell, but the way The Yellow Birds presents that hell is interesting, precisely because it's not that interesting.
It ends a sweeter, more meaningful film than it begins.
I know exactly who Steve Jobs, Apple CEO, is. Steve Jobs feels a revelation because it exposes Steve Jobs, the man.

So many films about America's past treat our sins as though they've all been washed away. Mudbound, like the best of its ilk, knows that's not the case. It lingers on small indignities and tiny moments of grace.
Maggie could have been a rare treat... Instead, what we get is a genuinely new take that winds up feeling, somehow, like the same old stuff we've seen a million times before.

It has all the makings of a new childhood classic: it's got wonder and adventure and loads of humor, and ultimately winds up on the side of optimism - but it also has moments of genuine tragedy and danger.
Aided by awards-worthy performances from Joel Edgerton and especially Ruth Negga, Nichols delivers an intimate drama that feels all the bigger for keeping its scope so resolutely small.

An unfunny script doesn't get funnier just because it gets to use the F-word. Making a plotline more complicated doesn't make it more interesting or more meaningful. Easter eggs are only fun if they're clever.
Those willing to roll with the changes will find an entertaining comedy-adventure full of new characters, new gadgets, new monsters, and new possibilities.
The larger story is positively riddled with plot holes, and any sense of subtlety seems to have fallen right through them.
If Gal Gadot's all-too-brief appearance in Batman v Superman was promising, she fulfills that potential and then some in Wonder Woman.
Snatched feels disappointingly familiar.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 also serves as a reminder of why it is we keep coming back to these movies, even as we know every single time that the heroes will prevail and the world will not end: it's the characters, stupid.
Directors Adrian Buitenhuis and Derik Murray cover all the usual bases... But the film is never more interesting, or more poignant, than when Ledger turns the camera on himself.
The characters in this movie just repeat themes and explain plot points to each other, all in the same flat, droning monotone.
The humans, meanwhile, are largely left to stare in awe.

I won't presume to know how familiar the filmmakers are with social media, but I can say that The Circle feels like an anti-social media tirade written by someone who tried sending a tweet once and decided he hated it.
It's not enough to promise moviegoers that the two hours of movie they just sat through will pay off in another year or two or three, when the sequel arrives. They have to pay off now.
Oh, if only dead men told no tales. Then we might have avoided this fifth Pirates of the Caribbean adventure, which fails to justify its own existence in any way whatsoever.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's just a straightforward retelling of the original, with a few cosmetic changes tacked on to make it look like something else.

While The Fate of the Furious never quite reaches the heights of the last few installments, it still goes by at a breezy pace, and on the way delivers everything we've come to expect and love from this franchise.

It's far from perfect. But the characters are lovable, the world they live in is intriguingly weird, and all in all Suicide Squad offers a playful alternative to DC's more straightforward superhero films.
First love has rarely been depicted as beautifully or as movingly as it is in Luca Guadagnino's Call Me By Your Name, an adaptation of the André Aciman.

Goodnight Mommy filmmakers put viewers through hell with the implicit promise that they'll make it all worth it in the end. The biggest surprise, for me, was that they actually make good on that contract.
Everything about Arrival feels meticulously crafted, from the gorgeously composed shots to the Jóhann Jóhannsson score.

There are plenty of laugh-out-loud moments, many of which are intermingled with sob-out-loud moments. It helps greatly that first-time director Chris Kelly maintains a low-key, naturalistic vibe throughout.
I can't remember the last time I felt so little while watching a movie. I wasn't even bored, so much as just dazed, like I'd woken up in someone else's dream.
As failures go, Mojave is a pretty interesting one. But it's a failure nonetheless.
What results is a story that feels both fresh and timeless - and desperately needed, at a time when the world feels mean. Let's hope this one sticks around a while.
As Moonee, Brooklynn Prince is a revelation. There's not a single artificial note in her performance, just raw charm.
It's interested in subjective truths, in class differences, in our national self-image, and in our cultural obsession with scandal and celebrity.
What we don't need are more movies that treat black characters as props and backdrops for stories about white people, and black pain as entertainment and education for white people.
As a filmmaker's ambitious attempt to wrestle with big, answerable questions, Downsizing is an interesting artifact. As an actual movie, though, it's an awkward misfire.
The Lego Ninjago Movie comes down to a 'be yourself' message that's so half-hearted that, even as I'm typing this, I'm not entirely sure it was the message of the movie.

Battle of the Sexes is so shrewd in other areas that it's hard to complain. What Battle of the Sexes understands is that this match looked entirely different depending on which side you were rooting for.
What makes Stronger so powerful, though, is that it's not interested in cheap, easy inspiration.
What makes Coco rare is that it recognizes that the things that give your life meaning might be in opposition to one another, and asks you to consider what really matters most.
The supernatural Thelma is the coming-of-age experience in a nutshell: It's all about finding out who you are, with all the invigorating uncertainty and ambiguity that entails.
While Jumanji isn't interactive in the way of actual video games, it does its best to simulate that feeling by getting you on the same page with the players at every turn.

Black Panther perfects what the Marvel Cinematic Universe has always done so well: build a world so richly rendered, it's almost a letdown to reach the end of the film and realize it's time to return to our own reality.
Fifty Shades is a veritable orgy of ineptitude and unprofessionalism - which might not be a problem, except that the film also insists on showing everyone at work all the time.
Columbus crept up on me so gradually and quietly that I don't even know when I started to love it. When it was over, though, I was left with a sweet aftertaste that stayed with me for hours.
Perhaps the new Superman is closer to what the fans wanted. But he doesn't really feel like a character anymore. He, like the rest of his movie, feels like a focus group-approved concept.
There's a living, breathing soul at underneath all that makeup, at the center of all those tics, and Oldman makes him fascinating to watch.
The overall effect is kind of numbing, but from moment to moment it's the cinematic equivalent of a cotton candy sugar rush.
Part of the fun is going into mother! knowing as little as possible so that you and your friends can argue afterwards about what it all means.

One thing that hasn't changed at all in the past decade is the series' trademark mix of raunchy humor and heart-on-sleeve sentiment, and American Reunion is every bit as delightfully disgusting and crass as any of these movies have ever been.
Man Up is a classic romantic comedy about two people who are too old, too wise, too jaded for classic romantic comedies, and that's precisely why it works.
Scott Cooper appears to have made Black Mass under the assumption that his work was half done the moment he jotted the words "Boston-set crime drama" on a notepad.
The genius of Under the Shadow lies in the way it builds up the tension: slowly, almost imperceptibly at first, until I suddenly realized I was wound so tightly I wanted to scream.
Professor Marston and the Wonder Women doesn't reinvent the biopic - but it expands our ideas about the kinds of stories that biopics can tell.
Far too much of the film feels a laundry list of references to the original.
The Birth of a Nation isn't an easy story to watch, but it's one that absolutely demands to be told.
The third-act shootout is a staple of a certain kind of film, but in Ben Wheatley's Free Fire it's essentially the entire movie. Against all odds, it works.
A must-see spectacle.

It's fun. Magic Mike XXL moves along at a brisk clip, leaning into all the absurdities of its premise and giggling all the way. It's the cinematic equivalent of an afternoon spent drinking beer on the beach. Everyone's having a good time.

If The Bad Batch is an ultimately pointless journey, at least it's one that takes us through some genuinely new territory -- one populated by bodybuilding cannibals and soundtracked by '90s-style boomboxes.
Watts nails the timeless cornerstones of adolescence: the crippling anxiety mixed with brash confidence, the life-or-death dimensions of a crush, the impatience to grow up.
Yes, The Big Sick is a comedy, but it's a comedy that offers up about a million reasons to cry.
The thin characterizations might have been mitigated by livelier dialogue... But there's no poetry or personality in any of these words.
It is scary, yes -- but it's heartbreaking, too. And that, even more than the clown's nasty tricks, might be what lingers with you.

Despite its stated obsession with all things "peculiar," there's little about this movie that is actually surprising. It comes across like a movie going through the motions of setting up a franchise, not a movie eager to bring you on a wild adventure.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The message is timeless. Family matters. Tell people you love them. Despite its predictability, the movie works because it is completely without guile.
While it may seem like just a Christian 'Chick Flick on the Prairie,' it explores several deep theological and cultural themes that make for good viewing by men and women.
Succeeds as a comedy, as a glimpse at a tumultuous time in European history, and as a thoughtful look at the great lengths to which people will go for important relationships.
An excellent documentary with much to say about the Mountain Meadows Massacre, the most important being that the lives of the victims were not the only casualties.
movie_title: Burying the Past: Legacy of the Mountain Meadows Massacre (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A thorough examination (and debunking) of the claims that have blurred the term 'historical fiction,' stirred a cauldron of controversy, and spurred record-breaking sales.
Through its emphasis on characters and not merely action, Master does not let us forget that all individuals are souls with flesh and blood, not merely empty casualties of war.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A very loud, crazily colourful and delightfully strings-free romp -- fun while it lasted and fondly recalled, but not, alas, the big love we yearned for.
There's a definite seam of melodrama running right through A Girl at My Door. But Jung works with such clarity, and Bae and Kim are so strong, that the end product feels so very sharp.
Fassbender, as Macbeth, is bristling and demented in equal measure; Cotillard, as Lady Macbeth, is creepy and enthralling.

The talented cast is game and deserves better, especially Cooper, who is saddled with a dreadlocked fright wig that gives the impression he is performing all his scenes with a spongy blond octopus sitting on his head.
Manages to accomplish what few sequels can -- it equals the original and in some ways even betters it.
It's not just the vampires that are damned in Queen of the Damned -- the viewers will feel they suffer the same fate.
Thankfully, Patel does not take sides.
This has to be applauded for exploring a topical and sensitive subject in the widest commercial context. Interesting, entertaining and solidly executed.
The technically accomplished result is cheesy, engaging but unmemorable 'time-pass'
Not an unmitigated disaster but the absurd shootout climax pushes it into stock escapist revenge masala fare.
Its largely unsentimental treatment of its doomed protagonist results in a surprisingly uplifting weepie.
Steer clear of this juvenile, crass and commercial film, which seems intent on insulting our intelligence.
Admirable but frustratingly simplistic in places, this overlong drama feels a bit too heavily plotted in places. It is redeemed by the dignified performances from its seasoned cast.
This is a welcome study of Indian relationships, couples now feel free to explore love and life free from the shackles of a still largely patriarchal society. Cheers!
The result is enjoyable for its visual flair, but this is a shallow and overlong spin on West Side Story.
It's hard to take the singing and dancing rebels seriously.
The saddest thing about this mess is that it is deliberately and gleefully vacuous.
Silly, lightweight, overlong and unoriginal; this is nevertheless shameless romantic entertainment that will undoubtedly be a hit. Welcome back Raj!
movie_title: Rab Ne Bana Di Jodi (A Couple Made by God) (A Match Made in Heaven) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The hit soundtrack was naughty and suggestive; the lead pair totally convincing and adorable. Lovely.
It's such a disappointment that the end result is a bland, feeble fable.
If you have still not seen a proper Bollywood movie before, this is an ideal introduction to the joys of commercial Bombay cinema. Go see: smile and weep!
Like the title of one of its five songs, this film is 'tacky oh tacky' fun.
This works in the film's favour: it's loud, crude and unpretentious.
Bollywood's biggest sci-fi flick is a lazy musical mishmash of every stock feature of the genre.
This Bollywood sex comedy sequel is predictably loud, crude and offensive.
A superior and impressive remake of a much revered but crude 1990s Bolly cult classic.
This is largely a fast-paced fun trip.
Overlong and stuffed with too many catchy but unnecessary songs, this worthy film is nevertheless indicative of a more sensible and sensitive side of Bollywood.
The solid performances of the lead actors ground the fantasy, while there are lots of elaborate set-pieces and witty one-liners to sustain interest.

Chennai Express - Bolly's biggest release of 2013 - is a shameless, silly and shallow 'masala' entertainer which represents, yet again, everything that is reprehensible about mass commercial Hindi cinema.
This Bollywood remake of the Tom Cruise/Cameron Diaz romcom action caper Knight and Day is just as derivative and dumb as the original.
Unlike the somewhat enjoyable original, which was an over the top retro kitsch throwback to '80s Bollywood, this follow up has arty pretensions.
A capable supporting cast and a fun cameo from a male megastar add to the appeal of this slight, enjoyable but ultimately predictable journey.
Warner Bros second foray into Bollywood is a brainless masala potboiler.
Even die-hard fans of utter Bollywood poppycock may feel cheated by this mindless 'masala' movie.
What's really shocking is that a talented director like Varma has used a real-life tragedy to produce Bolly-gore porn while passing it off as serious cinema.
If you've never seen a Tamil blockbuster before, this is not a good way to start.

The inclusion of unnecessary background songs (not subtitled) and a romantic subplot result in a sluggishly paced story, which is further undermined by a lengthy flashback and a preposterous final reveal.
The title translates as 'shameless': everyone involved should be thoroughly ashamed of themselves.
'Bollywood' and 'realism' may not go hand in hand, but this is a worthy and largely successful attempt at meaningful commercial Hindi cinema.
Kumar is in serious mode and brings a certain dignity to his one-dimensional character. Frustratingly, an unconvincing subplot is concocted in order to justify Cynthia's cheating.
Himesh's nine songs are hummable but, like this rehash, immediately forgettable.
There is an angry film waiting to be made on the current oppression of rural women in India. Sadly, this is sugary, superficial and intent on simplifying complex issues.
This represents everything that is laughable about masala Bollywood movies and glorifies rampant 'macho' behaviour in sexist modern Indian society.
Bollywood assaults our sensibilities again with yet another seriously embarrassing sequel.
Mehra's follow-up to his Bafta-nominated Rang de Basanti is another gritty slice of political Bollywood cinema.
Bachchan's millions of die-hard fans will be in speechless bliss.
The leads are charming and the dialogue has a knowing wit.
It remains a landmark film responsible for establishing Bollywood's early global presence.
It is marred by the usual bolly-excesses: an inordinate length, unnecessary songs and the miscasting of real-life royal-blood Khan as a 'dalit' (untouchable). Well acted, though.
Kohli's unsentimental direction results in a magical technically-polished universal crowd-pleaser which can rival any recent Disney fantasy.
Technically accomplished, it's always engaging due to the credible performances from its beautiful leads, the charismatic Khan and Kajol. Worthy, but flawed.
What follows is a three- and-a-half-hour journey back in time to a bygone era, well worth a visit.
Forget the plot, this is a shameless showcase for its ageing, A-list lead.
Once you decide to suspend all belief in logic from the preposterous proceedings, there is much to enjoy in this witty and inventive camp entertainer.
Moving, credible and tragic.
The mood is light, the acting generally subtle and the gentle jibes at traditional Indian mores outweigh some of the implausible edges in the script.
It's a low-key message movie, but it still packs a punch.
It is certainly one of the best Bollywood movies you will see in 2007.
Audiences seeking mild diversion might prefer approaching it as Lola does her new surroundings: 'The challenge is to find joy in simple things'.
Go see and get swept away in this festal melange of colour, sights and sounds.
Only Bachchan's customary cameo (temporarily) lifts the spirits.
This fluffy cross-cultural experiment smacks of jumping on the Bollywood bandwagon with little insight into the genre it is trying to emulate or understanding of the country in which it's set.
A little more restraint in maintaining the tonal consistency would have resulted in a much darker and satisfying cautionary tale about the perils of fame and blind love.
Ultimately forgettable, but overall it is efficient, entertaining and good-looking escapism.
If you find the idea of an alien landing in India and boogying with pelvic thrusts to saucy songs funny, this is for you. Otherwise, it's a joke of a film.
A rewarding and emotional watch.
Sarbjit is at times genuinely moving and features a family reunion sequence that will reduce you to tears.
Raavan is ravishingly good.
Akhtar's little-boy-lost vulnerable charm holds it all together.

The performances are pitch perfect, with A-lister Khan proving yet again that he's the most versatile and intelligent Indian actor of his generation. The result is probably the best mainstream Hindi film of 2014.

The physical beauty and real acting talent of the three leads rises this to just above sud-level. Its central message that 'all religions preach love, but love has no religion' is to be commended, especially since it is still so pertinent to India today.
Proves firmly that Bollywood can hold its own technically against its Western counterparts.
'King Khan' holds it all together.
It's a slick journey across Thailand, Malaysia, Switzerland and Germany which even manages to refer to the current Euro crisis.
Performances are uniformly impressive, with Khan proving again that he is the finest actor of his generation.
This quirky well-acted film proves, as the title track says, that generally 'all is well' with commercial Hindi cinema.
Forgettable fun.
A sumptuous if rather soulless love story.
The result is a tense, well crafted drama that lacks the deep emotional intensity required in its disturbed characters.
Bollywood's big Diwali release is an unashamedly overblown, three-hour masala movie which largely succeeds in its unambitious aim of providing mindless entertainment.

The only interesting aspect of this slick and superficial film is Bollywod's continued ability to waste rupees on expensive foreign location shooting instead of hiring a half-decent scriptwriter or sending its beautiful leads to acting school.
It largely succeeds due to its charismatic, handsome leads and a cracking 'Spanglish' soundtrack.
Depending on your cinematic sensibilities, this energetic, exhausting film can be regarded as festive fun or a tikka turkey.
Worth seeing but go with low expectations.
The film claims to champion the power of the common man, but it looks more like Khan and his director brother, Sohail, are intent on underestimating their common sense.
Kumar equates stripping to emoting whilst Ahuja and Balan share zero on-screen chemistry and look confused. Pretty Patel is reduced to an inexplicable cameo.
This woolly mix of hilarity and horror works best when played for baaad laughs. One thing is sure - it will put you off doner kebabs for life.
Have you ever tried adding salsa to the classic South Indian spicy relish sambar? It's a recipe for disaster, like this unappetising film which simply fails to sizzle.
Ultimately, this is yet another superficial style over substance journey which may alienate even fans of star-driven Bollywood vehicles.
Apparently, it is all about friendship and the power of imagination. But Karnik rams his message home, and is more intent on showcasing a touristy Rajasthan than focusing on characterisation.
You may agree with Narsimha'a wife when she chivvies him about his Babban obsession: "Babban! Babban! Nonsense! Waste of time!"

The film jogs along uncertain whether it is aiming to be an episode of Friends or a Farrelly brothers farce. Overrun with fart jokes, it is fitfully funny and hamstrung by a sentimental and implausible plot.
This is a mushy, gooey time-pass. Hey, if you are interested in seeing the men do a half-Monty, stick around for the closing credits.
Although intended to celebrate Bollywood, this Marigold smells suspiciously of trying to cash in on the current global obsession for all things Bollywood.
Although predictable and with a preachy patriotic 'United India' message, this is a heartfelt, heady, homage to hockey.
The inexplicable proceedings would be bearable - this is a massala movie after all - if the film could make up for in laughs what it lacks in substance. But it is shoddily assembled.
There is little here which intelligently explores, more so justifies, the film's dubious assertion that everyone has 'disguised intentions'.
It's bolly-fluff, fitfully funny in places but it is time to deport this NRI escapism back to Bollywood.
It all rings true but the pace drags, and the pretentious placement of the annoying songs with the non-stop appearance of an ugly bunch of rockers is simply irritating.
Only connoisseurs of utter bolly-poppycock will be inclined to linger on until the final credits.

Paying scant attention to either historical accuracy or character complexity, the Xena: Warrior Princess director Lefler goes for a straightforward good versus evil plot with a predictable climactic battle.
It's superior Bollywood soap, saved by the acting, which just about manages to raise it above sud-level.
movie_title: Laaga Chunari Mein Daag - Journey of a Woman (2007)

movie_review_blurb: By the end frustrated viewers may want to kick Kashyap's butt.
This is a rather conventional and surprisingly charming Bolly-romcom.
It's a mystery why Fox backed this 'masala' flick especially as no effort was made to market it to a wider audience.
For a film which invites us to 'come, let's dance', there is not a single number which encourages us to. Bring back the cheekiness of the choli!
After the first hour, the film becomes a repetitive and laborious time-pass.
As the title literally translates, this is bunkum-style over substance, and we the audience are THE 'tashan' victims.
This is a heretical and welcome take on the 'parents decide and children accept' formulaic bolly-melodrama. But worthy intentions cannot compensate for this father's flaws.

Hashmi is credible as the irredeemably misogynistic and volatile Arjun but his one dimensional character, presented as an amoral delusional shyster from the outset, lacks adequate emotional depth to evoke empathy.
With some witty special effects and the seasoned performances of the A-list stars, Bhoothnath works best when it focuses on the spooky antics between ghost and humans.
Mildly progressive sequences are swamped by the constant comic-strip pile-up of cars which ultimately makes this a stock exploding racing car action hokum.
This is especially welcome since premature senility is often misunderstood and can be considered a taboo topic in India.
Worst of all is its pretentious attempt at seriousness.
Pessimistic, realistic and ultimately uplifting, Halla Bol's predictable and passionate plea for justice emerges victorious.
If you ignore its flaws, I am Legend can be enjoyed as the perfect brainless Boxing Day blockbuster - but it is essentially a leftover festive turkey.
An ambitious attempt to push the boundaries of the traditional massala formula. However, two out of ten stories hitting the mark does not make this experiment a success.
Everyone involved with this missed Goal deserve red cards.
At times this is a disturbingly brilliant portrayal of a derailed and deranged life.
Sony's first major delve into the lucrative global Bollywood market is an admirable, ambitious misfire.
This extraordinary tacky offering has no redeeming features; it is a catalogue of ineptness.
There are some witty lines which manage to score laughs but Hattr!ck as a whole misses the wicket.

However, it is ironic that a black and white film which cautions against the indiscriminate use of technology for the acquisition of wealth should be subject to a colourisation process in order lure new lucrative audiences in.

Phir Milenge is a worthy attempt by the Mumbai industry to address a still taboo topic in the widest commercial context with three major stars - Shetty, Salman Khan, Abhishek Bachchan - and some catchy tunes.
[Bombay Velvet] is lengthy, violent and emotionally shallow but brilliantly stylish bolly-noir.
As Indian cinema celebrates one hundred years of production this month, this violent film represents its current confused state.
This would be forgivable if the shallow emotions worked but it's hard to care about these callous characters. Worst of all is its inability to address 'genius disorder' in any meaningful way.
It's an embarrassing excuse for a madcap comic caper.
There is much to enjoy in this unapologetic attempt to create a unique Indian superhero flick.
This is a one-note film that never manages to break free from the limitations imposed by its own clichéd plot. Nevertheless, it's camp fun. Meow!
Lead actors Khan and Kaif try their best, but what's most impressive is how Kaif's hairstyle remains intact after every high-flying chase.
Its profound 'knowledge is power which must be used responsibly' message is laughable.
Bollywood's latest assault on our sensibilities is a preposterous romantic thriller.
The plot is simply an excuse for Khan to trash guys who harass girls, make a smoke bomb, help star-crossed lovers elope, breakdance and steal from the rich to help sick, poor children.
Set in present day Rajasthan, India, this stunningly beautiful film is a worthy, if not largely successful, attempt at commercial Bollywood cinema.
There is much to admire in this big budget Hindi film that never falls into the trappings of the 'masala' formula.
This Bollwood take on the classic Arabian Nights tale fails to cast a spell.
Only the cinematography of a stunningly beautiful landscape ravaged by war comes close to making this unroadworthy vehicle a mildly memorable journey.
Aishwarya Rai-Bachchan makes a disappointing comeback in a dull thriller.
Will Auro survive to know his Pa and reunite his parents? Forget about the disease: this is a vanity vehicle designed to showcase the Big B's versatility.
Kukunoor has delivered a charming feelgood film. This is largely down to his charismatic cast, who win us over with their intense, poignant performances. The result is often superbly entertaining.
Salman Khan may be a huge star, but this outdated comedy doesn't make the best of his abilities.
Kumar delivers another hammy performance; Kapoor equates pouting to acting. Dammit! It's regressive!
Despite progressive intentions, its breezy and unchallenging view of modern day Mumbai life where everyone lives in harmony and is share-obsessed is too simplistic.
[Raees] is a fiery slice of Bollywood action.
There is much to admire in this attempt to push the Bollywood envelope. It's rare for mainstream Hindi cinema to feature such sensitively drawn characters.
It is redeemed by an accomplished performance from the talented handsome male-lead and by songs which rock.
Bollywood's attempt at a serious wartime romance is something of an ambitious misfire.
The result is a contrived, muddled masala movie meant only for die-hard fans of these two dummies.
Snoop Dogg's Bollywood debut is a mindless massala flick meant solely for fans of utter bolly-poppycock.
Superstar Bollywood director Karan Johar keeps his fans happy with a bittersweet globetrotting romance.
A largely unknown confident cast, rousing folk music and Rizvi's understated direction result in a fresh, credible comic gem.
The result is unpretentious, mindless Bollywood entertainment.
It drones on, taking itself far too seriously without any understanding of the genre it is trying to emulate. Bachchan and Chopra emote by slapping on as much mascara as possible.
[Khatta] is a muddled Bollywood attempt at satire on the hardships faced by the common man in order to progress in modern India.
Different but not groundbreaking (an Indian woman loves only once!) this NRI (Non Resident Indian) bolly-romcom, set entirely in America, is undemanding and unpretentious.
This is superior political cinema with an Indian heart.
This cocktail is more virgin than bloody Mary.
It is nice to see cricket being used as a metaphor for ameliorating relations between India and Pakistan. East or West? Good heavens, it's the Punjab that's the best!
movie_title: Dil Bole Hadippa! (My Heart Goes Hooray!) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The pacing is measured and it succeeds in revealing accurate comparative insights into the socio-mores of past and present Indian society that shape relationships.
Seasoned horror fans might be able to figure out where it's going before the third act, but Jakobsen and the cast handle everything so well that it's still a thrill ride getting there.
Tinfoil hats aside, Alien Contact: Outer Space is an entertaining watch.

6 Models in Hell is certainly one to check out providing you go in with an open mind and are prepared to overlook some shortcomings. As a taster for what the talented cast and crew could do, however, it's a great calling card.
It's actually much better than the film that arguably inspired it.
As a bold experiment in art, it's a fascinating and enthralling - if desperately depressing - journey. The animators involved are all highly skilled and certainly succeed in making their point.
The screenplay for The D Train, which is rooted in humor, lends itself to an entertaining take on a worthy, if not entirely original, message.
While that makes for an intriguing experiment, the results are at times befuddling -- and, even more often, underwhelming.
Poignant without being melodramatic, overflowing with unforced charm, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl holds a unique appeal that's certain to last.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some of the usual Bollywood razzle-dazzle, this might be the most authentic performance Khan has done on screen in a decade.
This is a movie of remarkable scale; on the level of sheer craftsmanship, it offers some appeal. If only Gowarikar had put the same level of effort into the story.
It amounts to little more than frothy summertime entertainment-occasionally fun, but almost immediately forgettable.
In not knowing whether it wants to be a heartfelt, chilling or activist story, Irada ends up being none, suggesting that perhaps good intentions aren't always enough.
It's all pleasant enough, but falls short of being as genuinely different as Clean Slate claims its films to be.
Confused and confusing about where it's going or what it's trying to say.
... "Simran," only fulfills part of the promise.
Ultimately, the film asks us to just "believe" in way too much else that's indigestible.
Badrinath Ki Dulhania may hit several faulty notes as a flag-bearer for feminism, but as delivered by this endearing duo, it's bound to touch more than a few hearts.
We may now have jarring insights into the mother, the activist and the tortured soul at the root of Simone's career, but it's the legendary songstress who ultimately shines through.
Shocking but genuine, poignant and hilarious, Diary of a Teenage Girl could well become one of the more memorable entries in the Sundance Film Festival's U.S. competition.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While "Justice for Jordan" may have been served, the words - and Davis' story - are yet another reminder of a nation that remains fractured by inequality, desperately in need of change.
There's no doubt that Bollywood could stand to have more women action heroes, but it could definitely have done without Akira.
Gauri Shinde's latest film is an emotionally resonant look at an issue that rarely gets covered in Indian society - therapy.
In the capable hands of actors who can siphon the nuances from a screenplay soaked in cliches, Ae Dil Hai Mushkil has many shining instances that reveal the poignant story Johar intended to tell.
The best part of the film, ironically, is the treatment of the musical numbers, a department that's usually the downfall of many Bollywood movies.

Where visuals, tone and treatment are concerned, Basu has given us a film unlike anything we've seen in recent Indian cinema, proving, if nothing else, the endless possibilities of a boundless imagination.
Even though the Joffrey, founded nearly 50 years ago, has powerful work in its repertory, the film emphasizes dance that is pretty and a touch vapid.
One of the most bizarre and extraordinary dance movies you'll ever see.
movie_title: Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary (2003)
